- -'adau.definition: fond of, crazy about, favorite thing

examples.english: I'm fond of oranges, I just love oranges.
She's fond of rasp- berries, she just loves raspberries. [GT, MMc]

notes: The initial prefix on this word agrees with the initial prefix on the word naming the thing liked. The possessive prefix refers to the person who likes the thing named. For ex- ample: I-cha-'adau i-gunat "She's fond of salmon"

Clearly related to Warm Springs word átau. When the possessive prefix is a single consonant, there occurs with this word the sequence consonant+glottal stop, which other- wise is not known to occur in Wasco. (In Wasco, a glottal stop normally occurs either at the beginning of a word or between vowels, but not after another consonant.) Hence, it is almost certain that this word was borrowed from Warm Springs to Wasco rather than the other way around.

forms.english: he was floating; he is floating (in this direction)
they 2 are floating about [*shuxninan is not acceptable]
it is floating to the surface
he is floating up to the surface toward her
he is drifting away from him [Dyk]
he drifted along [WTI.1a1] [said of Coyote after he turned himself into a piece of wood for Swallow sisters to pick up]

notes: A place in Cascade country, now called Lacamas. Literally "her calico fish."

examples.english: I'm going to the toilet to defecate [PK 7/10/ 56]
He's going to defecate.
She's going to defecate. [GT, MMc 1/14/ 99]

notes: Used mostly of babies.
Borrowed from (or to?) Warm Springs Sahaptin ámush. A long shell with a twist on the end. [GT 1/14/99]

a-mulal.definition: onion-like root, amulal amumda [vb] you will grow

aa.definition: assent, agree, decide, make up one's mind

examples.english: He made up his mind. [WTIV.2.17]

examples.kiksht: Ag̲a kwapt gayułait isk'ulya daba akłmín ailgachxix.
examples.english: Now then Coyote sat down here (where) the moon is descending to the ground. [WTI.9.8]

notes: Literally "place (-ix) the-sun (ag̲ałax) it (a-) enters (-upg̲emd-) into (-l-) it (-i-; that is, the place where the sun goes when it sets)."

examples.english: He was puzzled. [Dyk]
I am puzzled. [PK]

aaima.definition: only she, only her, only it[a-]

examples.english: Only she is staying at home. [DykGr 119]
You stole him. [Dyk]

notes: The only known use of this word is in a legend, where it refers to ghosts.

examples.english: [He] cut off a little, threw away, one village [came into being]. [WTI.1m.6]

notes: Note from Sapir: "-ai- denotes the ease with which the cutting was done; the over-long -a- ... implies the continuous slice-like character of the cut." [WT p.145]

examples.english: He cut the meat. [WTI.14.3]
Her father will cut off his hair. [WTII.3.1]
He just made him black on his nose. [WTI.17.14]

acdemluda.definition: he will give them to you

examples.english: He would try to seize her, but without success. [WTI.17.12]

achdenshlux̲a.definition: he will make them for us

achditłama.definition: he will report them to him, he will come bring them to him

examples.kiksht: Shmanix̲ achditłama yak'ila kwapt nachdupg̲nayabåt stuxw ałx̲ux̲wa łax̲ka qi łx̲lá.
examples.english: If he reports to the trainer (that he has done) as many as he had appor- tioned, the one that trains is re- leased. [WTII.9.2]
Wherever he will command him, there he will bring them. [WTII.9.1]

notes: Probably used to address a younger sister bigger than one ad- dressed with aci.

examples.kiksht: Idiałx̲iwulx ich'inun; p'ala pu achigelgaya iqwaqwa iaxan.
examples.english: Eagle is strong; he could seize a grizzly- bear's son without being harmed. [WTI.4.8]

achiugwichima.definition: he will strike them with it[i-]

examples.kiksht: Achtudinaya idelxam iatalamqsqit amni; alma achiugwichima idelxam; achtuwalalma.
examples.english: He will kill the people with his battle axe; he will strike them with it; he will chase them around. [WTI.4.8]

achátshgama.definition: he will come to marry her

achłx̲ukshtama.definition: he will go look at that of his[ił-], he will go look at what he[ił-] has done

examples.kiksht: Qauad idbinałx̲ ałkdux̲wa iłk'ashkash, achłx̲ukshtama iyagikshtamnił.
examples.english: The inspector goes to see how many wood-ropes the boy makes. [WTII.9.2]

achłx̲ímaya.definition: he will let him[ił-] go, he will send him[ił-] off

notes: Probably used to address a sister smaller than one addressed with achi but bigger than one ad- dressed with cina.

adamluda.definition: I will give them to you

adamshluda.definition: I will give them to you folks

adau.definition: esteem, value, think much of, treasure

examples.english: He re- spected him, held him important.
I think much of it.
I think much of my daughter.
for esteem- ing, for valuing; as a keepsake
He gave it[i-] to me as a keepsake.
She is esteemed.
Let's not you and I think much of each other.
I'm travelling on a reverent journey.
They are getting together for an important occasion (for instance, a funeral). [Dyk]

notes: Borrowed from or to Sahaptin átau.

adelgátgwama.definition: they will come, they will get here

adnenk'namxida.definition: I would be satisfied with them, they would sat- isfy me

Hello, you 2, where are you going?
Look! Look! Look! [Dyk]

notes: Appears to express surprise, warning, or admonition.
adáy.pronunciation: Pronounced some- what as if written in English: a-day.

examples.english: Oh! I can't go.
That's the way (said to praise a child)!

notes: An exclamation of astonish- ment.
Exclamation used when one gets hurt.

enough, quit now
Now I die.
Let's go now.
Now let's you and I go.
Did you recognize/remember them at that time?
He strictly never drinks. [Dyk]

ag̲a pu.definition: almost, pretty near ag̲utx [n] my mother's sister!, (ma- ternal) aunt!
notes: Used to address one's mother's sister.

Hello, friend. [Dyk]

notes: Not used with verb -x "do".

Someone makes him of necessity, it has to be done.

How is it to be done?

He will be forced to cook for himself.
They had to take her away on their backs (because she either refused or was unable to go by her- self.
something that has to be towed
I'll have to go on foot.
You'll have to go on foot. [Dyk]

notes: It may be the case that this should be considered two different words with the same sound, one meaning "just, only" and the other meaning "necessarily, forced to." In the latter meaning, it contrasts with the concept of something being self- moving or self-chosen.

According to Gladys Th- ompson and Madeline McInturff [6/ 3/98], however, it refers to bread baked standing up on edge of fire; bread baked in ashes is ushít asablal. aixwáu [part] be interested in what one does, interest in what one does

He is interested in what is being done and does it him- self. [Dyk]

Gladys Thompson and Madeline McInturff [6/5/98] confirm meaning as given, although uncertain of the details of the procedure. Gladys says axelgidugwaya would mean the same thing, but questioned this form "be- cause it was always a man [who car- ried the proposal]"

notes: Used in combination with future tense to indicate futurity (as opposed to other modal senses of future, as for instance possibility or potentiality).

examples.english: Oh, boy! where are you go- ing? [WTI.11.5]

alłxelmama.definition: we will go eat, let's go eat

examples.english: Oh the stinker! [WTI.18.7]

amalimałxíxida.definition: you will fall into the water

amaluxwa.definition: you will make it[a-] for her

notes: A child's term for addressing her or his father. An alternate form is ámamash. [Dyk] This word is perhaps not in current use. [Relatives]
A child's term for addressing her or his father. An alternate form of ámama. [Dyk] This word is per- haps not in current use. [Relatives]

notes: Madeline McInturff thinks this refers not to harness as such but to putting decorations for a parade over a horse. She and Gladys Thomp- son were unable to supply other forms [1/12/99].

amshxelp'álawulalma.definition: you folks will talk to one another

amtkłnidama.definition: you 2 will go get her[ił-] for me

notes: Used to address either one's father's brother or a stepfather.

notes: The absence of a final -a suf- fix in this future tense verb is un- usual. Perhaps it was elided (slurred over) before the word aish which began the following sentence.

notes: Means "eighth month." This implies that the Wasco year began around September. Two people gave walishnan as a possible name for April. [DH]
Used only to address father's sister, mostly by children.

notes: Used to address one's father's sister.

examples.kiksht: Kánawi shan pu ikaqmit ałgiuxa dayaba iq'ílaitix. C'em ixa!
examples.english: Everyone has a voice in making laws on the reservation. Vote! [Spilyay/ Vote]

ałgiuxwa.definition: they will do it[i-] [WTI.14.4], he[ił-] will do it[i-] [WTII.9.1]

examples.english: They will win at bones. [WTI.4.8]

ałgnuwag̲wa.definition: he[ił-] will kill me [WTI.1d.4], they will kill me [WTIV.1.4]

notes: The root -gula- is an alternate form of the root -gla-.

ałgłxátgwaya.definition: he[ił-] will pile them up on one another

ałg̲iwitxida.definition: they are going to bed, they are going to sleep

ałigułxa.definition: he will walk out from shore on it[i-]

ałkdugwatxaimaulxma.definition: he[ił-] will haul them up onto it[it-]

ałkduxwa.definition: he[ił-] will make them [WTII.9.2], they will do them, they will catch them [WTIV.1.3]

ałkduxwama.definition: he[ił-] will go to make them

examples.english: I'll see you later. [CLL16]

notes: A compound of ałqi "later" and alma "in future."

ałqi.definition: later, after a while, for a while

examples.english: wait a little while
'Let's go now.' 'Wait a while.'
Go to him for a while!
You will go to him after a while, later on.
You will go to him for a while.
I'll go there for a while.
Let's go now, put it off for a while.
He won't come for some time yet.
Let him come for a while.
You'll do it[i-] later.

examples.kiksht: Diká nigikiax sqitłaq kwapt ałg̲i niyagluya.
examples.english: He stayed here, during which time he went to her for a while.
not until then
not until I sing [Dyk]
Wait a while! Later! [PK 6/29/56]

notes: When a word beginning with a vowel follows, the -i of ałqi is elided (dropped) if it means "for a while;" but if it means "later, after a while," the -i is retained. See examples.

examples.english: His penis is just like rope. [WTI.1c.1]

aługwig̲éliudama.definition: they will go to meet her at her house

ałumqta.definition: it will die [WTI.2.24, II.2.3], he[ił-] will die [WTI.9.13], they would die [WTIV.3.2]

ałuya.definition: it will go [WTI.1c.6], he[ił- ] will go [WTII.9.2]

examples.kiksht: Aish k'ala amshgnuxa k'mekedesh gigwáladamt ichq'aqshtaq, qádachix iłqawulqt daława ałuya gigwáladamt wilxyamt.
examples.english: Just carry me on my back so that my head is downward, so that my blood will flow downward to the ground. [WTI.1c.6]

notes: Literally "it will settle."

ałxatxa.definition: it will become [WTII.7.2], they will become [WTIV.2.22]

ałxlaya.definition: he[ił-] will move himself, he[ił-] will train

examples.kiksht: Dauya ich'axwi yunułemix kiksht ik'inułem engi.
examples.english: This letter isw ritten in Wasco. [DykGr 121]

notes: This is a word for "this" usedwith nouns beginning with i-.

galix̲ux̲.definition: he made himself, he turned himself into, he became, they[i-] did, he did himself. it[i-] came to be

examples.english: He turned himself into a piece of wood. [WTI.1a1]
The elks drummed. [WTI.15.4]
He rubbed himself. [WTI.17.17]

notes: Used only by or to children.
Borrowed from English.

forms.english: my father [Note special form, with possessive prefix - n- and suffix -sh; compare wanaqsh (my mother).]

examples.english: her many fathers [Dyk]

notes: winamsh can also be used for address.

examples.english: one hundred
170 of us [Dyk]

id-náchk.definition: fish, at the time they are running plentifully, fish run

examples.english: Coyote heard about two women having the fish run. [WTI.1.1]
our ways of old, our traditions [Museum 4]

ishktälgwipchk.definition: they 2 collected them from water (into it[i-]?)

examples.english: They 2 were collecting them from the river. [WTI.1a.1]

notes: Borrowed from English; an English word used with Wasco pre- fixes.
Composed of alakas "mouse" and -lgwilit "appearance."

kinwa.definition: try, in vain, futilely, no matter

examples.english: He tried (to get them to pick him up) by turning himself into a piece of wood. [WTI.1a1]
no matter what; nothing will do [Dyk]
Then he went to them. [WTI.1a.1]
What else? [GT, MMc]
again the same, the same again
and then
enough, quit now
Then I came home.
Every once in a while she'll steal their acorns from them.
'How many horses do you have?' 'Two.' 'Is that all?' 'That is all, only that many.' [Dyk]
How are you? [GT, MMc]
Do something to me! [WTI.5.3]
What's the matter?
What are you travelling for?
What is this that happened to me?
What's the matter with you?
How is it to be done?
What did he do to him?
What's the matter?
He is doing everything to him.
nothing, nothing the matter
Why don't you work at Berkeley? [Dyk]

examples.kiksht: Amuya awachi naika anuya, qengi ch'ala?
examples.english: You'll go or I'll go, how about it?

examples.kiksht: Wax anłuxwa iłk'iwaxmat awachi kwaish, qengi ch'ala?
examples.english: Shall I light the light now or after a while, what do you say? [Dyk]

seeAlso: qengiská, qengidnu qengi ch'ala [idiom]  "how about it?", "what do you say?"

examples.english: I'm sitting on the ground.
one year
this year; this ground
The Chinook salmon looked carefully over all the land.
Ground, ground it made itself (as when after the snow melts,ground appears everywhere) [Dyk]
She went to the river.
all along the river [Dyk's transcription: yaka we:mał] [Dyk]

examples.kiksht: G̲angadix galux̲wílaitix adasq'ú idelxam kana'amdmax̲ wimałba.
examples.english: Long ago the Wasco people lived on both sides of the Columbia River. [GT, MMc]

notes: Comment by Phillip Kahclamat: "Sapir said the Columbia is the only one called wimał, but I'd call the Amazon, Mississippi that." Apparently this word refers to large rivers. Compare wi-qał.

examples.english: Oh help me!
Oh you did me good! [Dyk]

notes: Most commonly a cry for help. Dyk labels it "a woman's word." See also: anáaa, aláaa

forms.english: I'm sick! I'm hurt! (used by children) [DykGr 141]

examples.english: Don't, you'll hurt yourself.
Gee, I hurt myself.
Gee it's hot [used by older people]. [Dyk]

notes: A term used by old people or by children, or to children to warm them not to do something dangerous or naughty.
